pullrequest.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw:
in general I'll be careful about protecting a visual update with a lock. A visual update should only happen in the main rendering thread and having a lock here means that there could be two more threads wanting to update the visual and this could cause a crash. 

Can `SetCoM` and other functions be called from other threads?
content.html:
in general I'll be careful about protecting a visual update with a lock. A visual update should only happen in the main rendering thread and having a lock here means that there could be two more threads wanting to update the visual and this could cause a crash.

Can SetCoM and other functions be called from other threads?

content.raw: I'm not sure what happens in which thread, but if somehow the user manages to set the CoM from the dialog (by changing link) and drag the torque visual with the mouse at the same time, it could be that `SetCoM` and `SetTorque` -> `SetMode` are called at the same time..?
content.html: I'm not sure what happens in which thread, but if somehow the user manages to set the CoM from the dialog (by changing link) and drag the torque visual with the mouse at the same time, it could be that SetCoM and SetTorque -> SetMode are called at the same time..?

pullrequest.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw: The problem is that `SetMode` calls `UpdateForceVisual` and handles the visuals directly as well, so to avoid using a recursive mutex, I locked this out here.
content.html: The problem is that SetMode calls UpdateForceVisual and handles the visuals directly as well, so to avoid using a recursive mutex, I locked this out here.

pullrequest.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw:
I can't see a problem in your code that would cause the test failure. I'm trying to reproduce the problem locally, but so far I've been unsuccessful. The tool itself seems to work very well.

You can move the test to the `ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS` in `gui/CMakeLists.txt`. This will help jenkins (by making the test not run).
content.html:
I can't see a problem in your code that would cause the test failure. I'm trying to reproduce the problem locally, but so far I've been unsuccessful. The tool itself seems to work very well.

You can move the test to the ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS in gui/CMakeLists.txt. This will help jenkins (by making the test not run).

pullrequest.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw: Someone ( @scpeters ?) suggested the Jenkins machine might have popups blocking the mouse clicks and stealing windows focus, so we might try disabling some warning popups in the Jenkins machine...
content.html: Someone ( @scpeters ?) suggested the Jenkins machine might have popups blocking the mouse clicks and stealing windows focus, so we might try disabling some warning popups in the Jenkins machine...

pullrequest.title: Rotate force/torque with mouse on Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw: Ok. But don't let it stop you. Putting the test in the `ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS` is a reasonable approach. We have other tests in this category, so we know that running tests locally is a must for a complete test run.
content.html: Ok. But don't let it stop you. Putting the test in the ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS is a reasonable approach. We have other tests in this category, so we know that running tests locally is a must for a complete test run.
